facts.title: Highest-Grossing Movie
facts.description: Currently, the highest-grossing movie in history is Avatar (2009) by James Cameron, earning over $2.9 billion, including re-releases.

facts.title: Oscar for Animation
facts.description: The category 'Best Animated Feature' was introduced in 2001. The first winner was Shrek.

facts.title: Most Expensive Scene
facts.description: In James Cameron's Titanic (1997), the sinking scene cost over $20 million — more than the actual ship cost in 1912.

facts.title: Hollywood Symbol
facts.description: The famous 'Hollywood' sign originally advertised real estate and read 'Hollywoodland.' Later, part of the sign was removed.

facts.title: Longest Acting Career
facts.description: Actor Norman Lloyd began acting in the 1920s and continued until his death in 2021, with a career spanning over 90 years.

facts.title: The 'Milk in Coffee' Effect
facts.description: In black-and-white films of the 1930s-40s, sauce or paint was used instead of milk in coffee to make it appear richer on screen.

facts.title: Silent Movies and Bees
facts.description: In the 1920s, directors sometimes used live bees to make actors cry in dramatic scenes by letting them buzz nearby.

facts.title: CGI in Blockbusters
facts.description: In Jurassic Park (1993), CGI only accounts for 14 minutes of screen time, even though the movie is famous for its revolutionary computer graphics.

facts.title: First Hollywood Film
facts.description: The first movie shot in Hollywood was the short western In Old California (1910), directed by D.W. Griffith.

facts.title: The Longest Film Ever Made
facts.description: The experimental movie 'Modern Times Forever' (2011) runs for 240 hours (10 days), depicting the gradual decay of a building over centuries.

facts.title: Hollywood's Oldest Studio
facts.description: Universal Pictures, founded in 1912, is the oldest operating film studio in Hollywood.

facts.title: Fake Snow in Classic Films
facts.description: In the classic film 'It's a Wonderful Life' (1946), fake snow was made using a combination of foam, sugar, and water to create a more realistic appearance than cotton.

facts.title: First Color Movie
facts.description: The first full-color movie was 'The World, the Flesh and the Devil' (1914), though color didn't become standard until much later.

facts.title: Biggest Oscar Winner
facts.description: Three films — 'Ben-Hur' (1959), 'Titanic' (1997), and 'The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King' (2003) — share the record for the most Oscars won (11).

facts.title: The Hollywood Walk of Fame
facts.description: The first star on the Walk of Fame was awarded to actress Joanne Woodward in 1960.

facts.title: The First Sound Film
facts.description: 'The Jazz Singer' (1927) is considered the first 'talkie,' introducing synchronized sound to the industry.

facts.title: Most Expensive Film
facts.description: 'Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides' (2011) remains one of the most expensive films ever made, with a budget of $379 million.

facts.title: Hidden Cameos
facts.description: Alfred Hitchcock made cameos in 39 of his films, often as an extra in the background.

facts.title: Record Number of Extras
facts.description: The 1982 film 'Gandhi' used over 300,000 extras in the funeral scene, the largest number in film history
